abstract.text: Any
shape with straight or curved lines
using relative points (positions or quadrantals).
Supports absolute sizing or implicit sizing to parent
on either or both axes, with optional adjustment.
For straight lined shapes with rounded corners or smoothing
use OpenSidedShape instead. See also Line w/other initialization
options. Very similar to this except Line is “flat” by default.
Any shape that is constructed relatively to the
container (e.g. using Positions or Quadrantals).
Any item that can be used as a reference for positioning
and sizing other items.
See also Queryable – the super-set of Referential.
Any positionable item that can also be “anchored”
on any point within its bounds for the purpose of
transformations.
Any item that has a frame with readable
and writable information.
Any item that can be scaled, rotated or translated.
Anything that can have an explicitly defined index.
Any type that can exist in SwiftUI.
This is used for optimizations depending
on if the item is within or without
a SwiftUI hierarchy.
Protocol for any object that is identifiable
and can be queried by identifier.
Objects that have matrix transforms which can be
decomposed from a single transform into it’s constituent
sub-transforms: scale, rotation and translation.
The protocol composition that views, layers, guides and nodes
conform to on all generic wrappers, such as Query, Mutator and others.
Access to layer on UIView (backing) or CALayer (self).
Implicitly sized shape
Any view or layer type that can be shallow copied.
Protocol for any object that is taggable.
A tag is an adhoc string like a CSS “class” that can
be used for identification, grouping, styling, etc.
Protocol to support storing and cancelling
Combine subscriptions.
An item that can store its latest view context
in order to have up-to-date information.
This information is usually transient and
doesn’t persist very long in the stack.
(i.e. not usually later than when the parent
scope exits.)
Views, layers and guides – can contain layers.
Internal protocol to support certain types to have runtime
control over control state dependency.
Any item that can be owned by a view
A protocol that provides an efficient low-level
interface to work with super/sub-items, non-recursively.
Create a sized shape using “quadrantals” which represent
points on a rectangle divided into 4 quadrants that
result in 5 x 5 (25) possible point positions, with
other positions being represented using expressible
array syntax for x,y between ~0 and ~1. Provide further
offsets using +/- infix operators or shift positions by
half with the +/- prefix/postfix operators. Example:
An orderable object denoted by an integer index.
Create a sized shape using “positions” which represent
points on a rectangle divided into quadrants that
result in 3 x 3 (9) possible point positions, with
other positions being represented using expressible
array syntax for x,y between 0 and 1.
Any item that has a frame with readable information.
Frequently accessed meta data stored on C3 types
(aka “OkayType”). This exists to ease adding new
meta types in the future and importantly as
an optimization over general KVC storage which
all of the meta types store for non-C3 types.
See Identifiable for notes and benchmarks.
Anything that can be added to a parent/child hierarchy.
OkayType indicates the UIView, CALayer, Guide or SKNode
is safe and optimized to use within this library.
Any item that can be cloned by having it’s state
copied over. Supports repeated or “data” items.
Protocol for classes/protocols that give access
to UIControl.state. Currently provided via:
Unified style properties on UIView and CALayer.
Any object that can have it’s animatable state saved
and restored at some point later.
Items that can have parent guides.
Any item that can be hidden or shown or visible
to a degree (alpha).
Types that can hold a background color.
Any item that can be positioned on its center point.
Any
shape with straight or curved lines
using relative points (positions or quadrantals).
Supports absolute sizing or implicit sizing to parent
on either or both axes, with optional adjustment.
For straight lined shapes with rounded corners or smoothing
use OpenSidedShape instead. See also Line w/other initialization
options. Very similar to this except Line is “flat” by default.
Flag to indicate an object is internal-only
and should therefore be excluded from queries.
This is marked “public” visibility so that it
can be part of Queryable (via MetaCodable) and
therefore eliminate (expensive) protocol casting.
Any coordinate space that can be converted to another.
Shape that is based on an open path
such as a multi segmented line with
straight or curved segments.
See also CGPath.allSubpathsAreClosed
for a way to dynamically check if a
shape is open or closed.
Any object that can access the environment
Any item than can be repeatedly constructed using
self as the base item.
Any item that can be reused and potentially transfer
state from a prototype or other item.
A protocol specialization on protocols that store
specific pieces of meta data, with the default
storage on layers via KVC.
Any item that can have a “container view”
The only difference between this and ViewAssociable
is that views return superview with this and
self with ViewAssociable. Other conformances
are the same.
Protocol to support updating the appearance of a dependent
item based on the control state of another item.
The default implementation of this protocol presumes the item
with control state is an ancestor, and returns the first
ancestor which has a control state. Or, override this method to
query for the control state item from anywhere else in the hierarchy.
Example: a Rectangle may be styled based on the state of it’s containing Button.
To achieve this, the Button would probably conform to ControlStateUpdatable.
Items that can discover their containing UIScene
Protocol to indicate that the type can be
manipulated using manual-frame changes via FreeLayout.
Transformable that takes transform matrices
such as CGAffineTransform and CATransform3D.
